Package cmpt355.project.util

Class Lists

java.lang.Object
cmpt355.project.util.Lists
public class Lists
extends Object
A class with static methods helpful for constructing and working with lists.

  • Nested Class Summary

    Nested Classes 
    Modifier and Type Class Description
    static class  Lists.Builder<T>
    A helper class (following the builder pattern) for creating a list.

      public Lists()

  • Method Details

    • builder

      public static <T> Lists.Builder<T> builder()
      Creates a new Lists.Builder object to be used in constructing a list.
      Type Parameters:
      T - the element type of the list that will eventually be generated

    • map

      public static <From,​ To,​ Ex extends Exception> List<To> map​(List<? extends From> list, FunctionEx<From,​To,​Ex> f) throws Ex extends Exception
      Returns a new list consisting of the result of applying f to every element of list. Any exception thrown by f while mapping elements is propagated out. Example use: 
      
      List<String> strings = ...;
      List<Integer> numbers = Lists.map(strings, Integer::parseInt); // throws NumberFormatException if parseInt() does on any of the strings
      Type Parameters:
      From - the data type being mapped from
      To - the data type being mapped to
      Ex - the type of exception that may be thrown
      Parameters:
      list - the list of values to be mapped
      f - the mapping function to apply
      Returns:
      a new list of the mapped values
      Throws:
      Ex - if f throws
      Ex extends Exception

    • forEach

      public static <E,​ Ex extends Exception> void forEach​(List<? extends E> list, ConsumerEx<E,​Ex> f) throws Ex extends Exception
      Applies f to every element of list. Any exceptions thrown by f are propagated out. Example use: 
      
     List<String> strings = List.of("x", "y", "z");
     Lists.forEach(strings, s -> System.out.printf("%s is a fine kettle of fish.\n"));
      The above code will print 
      
     x is a fine kettle of fish.
     y is a fine kettle of fish.
     z is a fine kettle of fish.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the data type of the values
      Ex - the type of exception that may be thrown
      Parameters:
      list - the list of values to apply f to
      f - the function to apply to list values
      Throws:
      Ex - if f throws
      Ex extends Exception

    • filter

      public static <E,​ Ex extends Exception> List<E> filter​(List<E> list, PredicateEx<E,​Ex> p) throws Ex extends Exception
      Returns a list of the values from list that satisfy the predicate p. Any exceptions thrown by p are propagated out. Example use: 
      
     List<String> strings = List.of("a", "bb", "ccc", "dddd");
     List<String> evenStrings = Lists.filter(strings, s -> s.length() % 2 == 0);
      In the above code, evenStrings will be ["bb", "dddd"] as those are the two strings whose length is even.
      Type Parameters:
      E - the data type of the values
      Ex - the type of exception that may be thrown
      Parameters:
      list - a list of values
      p - a predicate to apply to the values (takes a value as parameter and returns true or false)
      Returns:
      a list consisting of all values from list for which p returns true
      Throws:
      Ex - if p throws
      Ex extends Exception

    • zip

      public static <L,​ R> Iterable<Pair<L,​R>> zip​(List<? extends L> left, List<? extends R> right)
      Like Python's zip() builtin function, returns an iterable of pairs of values from the left and right lists. (In other words, makes it possible to use an enhanced for loop to iterate over values from two lists at the same time.) Example use: 
      
     List<String> strings = List.of("A", "B", "C");
     List<Integer> ints = List.of(1, 2, 3);
     for (var pair : Lists.zip(strings, ints)) {
         System.out.printf("%s / %d\n", pair.left, pair.right);
     }
      The above code prints 
      
     A / 1
     B / 2
     C / 3
      Type Parameters:
      L - the data type of the "left" values
      R - the data type of the "right" values
      Parameters:
      left - the list of "left" values
      right - the list of "right" values
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if left.size() != right.size()

    • reversed

      public static <E> List<E> reversed​(List<? extends E> list)
      Returns a reversed version of the given list; for example, if list is [1, 2, 3], this method returns [3, 2, 1]. The returned list is just a view of the parameter so no list values are actually copied. Consequently this method would be extremely inefficient to use if the parameter list were, say, a linked list. Accordingly, this method throws an IllegalArgumentException if the provided List does not implement RandomAccess. ArrayList is safe to use; if you have a non-random-access list that you want reversed and you're willing to make a copy of the list contents, use Lists.reversed(new ArrayList&lt;&gt;(list).
      Type Parameters:
      E - the data type of list elements
      Parameters:
      list - a list whose contents are to be reversed
      Returns:
      a new list with the same contents but in reverse order (does not actually copy the list contents)
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if list does not implement RandomAccess
